contentrichtext.text: {{ChineseText}} {{Anthropology of religion}} [[File:Tong2ji1.jpg|thumb|[[Chinese characters]] for ''tongji'']] '''Tongji''' ({{zh|c=童乩|p=''tóngjī''|w=''t'ung-chi''|l=youth diviner}}) or '''Jitong''' ({{zh|c=乩童|p=''jītóng''|w=''chi-t'ung''|l=divining youth}}) is a [[Daoist]] religious specialist, usually translated as a "[[spirit medium]]", "[[oracle]]", or "[[shaman]]". This word compounds ''tong'' [[Wikt:童|童]] "child; youth; boy servant" and ''ji'' [[Wikt:乩|乩]] "to divine" (cf. ''[[Fuji (planchette writing)|fuji]]'' 扶乩 "divination; planchette writing"). Regional variants include [[Hokkien]] ''tâng-ki'' 童乩 and [[Canton dialect|Cantonese]] ''gei-tung'' 乩童 or ''san-daa'' 神打. A ''tongji'' or ''jitong'' is a person believed to have been chosen by a particular ''[[shen (Chinese religion)|shen]]'' 神 "god; spirit" as the earthly vehicle for divine expression. The Chinese differentiate a ''[[wu (shaman)|wu]]'' 巫 "shaman; healer; spirit medium" who gains control of forces in the spirit world versus a ''tongji'' who appears to be entirely under the control of forces in the spirit world. Frequently a person who will become ''tongji'' experiences himself, at an early time in his or her life, to be coming under the compulsion of some god to be possessed by him. The person may well resist that compulsion. Should his resistance fail, he will from time to time enter into a [[altered state of consciousness|trance]] in which he may beat himself with a nail-studded ball at the end of a cord and handle to the point that he draws blood from multiple wounds on his back. While in this trance state he will experience himself, and the members of his community of belief will experience him, as speaking the words of that god. ==External links and references== *Andersen, Poul. 2008.
